titleStmt.title: Description of Folger Shakespeare Library, MS V.a.84: Appollogeticus ... etc. manuscript, 1504.

availability.licence: These images and the content of Folger Shakespeare Library MS V.a.84: Appollogeticus ... etc. manuscript, 1504. are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. This work is published from: United States. For a summary of CC0, see https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/. Legal code: https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/legalcode.

notesStmt.note: In Latin, with some works translated from Greek.
For a bibliographical description of this manuscript see The book collector, 24, no. 1 (Spring 1975).
Ricci, S. de. Census of medieval and Renaissance manuscripts in the United States and Canada, SM.7.

msContents.summary: Contains Gregory's apology for his unworthiness for ordination to the priesthood, with a preface by its translator, Rufinus of Aquila; two Lenten sermon fragments by Maximus the Confessor; and Ambrose's letter to Irenaeus.

respStmt.persName: Verney, Ralph Verney, Earl, 1714-1791, former owner.
Smedley, William T. (William Thomas), 1851-1934, former owner.
Folger, Emily C. J. (Emily Clara Jordan), 1858-1936, former owner.

msItem.title: Lenten sermon fragment by Maximus the Confessor
msItem.incipit: [rubr.] Ex sermone beati Maximi episcopi. Feria sexta in quadragesima. [text] Quia fratres charissimi ieiunantis domini victoriam recensentes triumphum nostre salutis agnovimus ...
msItem.explicit: ... ad gaudia celestium promissionum indubitata fidutia et conscientia letiore veniemus. [f. 1v]

msItem.title: Lenten sermon fragment by Maximus the Confessor
msItem.incipit: [rubr.] Idem Maximus in alio sermone. Sabbato in xl prime ebdomade. [text] Si igitur, fratres, nolumus a diabolo superari, inhereamus ei qui diabolum triumphavit ...
msItem.explicit: ... fidutia letioris conscientie et cum tranquillitate temporum transigemus. [f. 2v]

msItem.title: Rubric for Gregory's Apology and Preface
msItem.incipit: [rubr.] Appologia hec diui Gregorii Nazanzeni scripta est expensis venerabilis viri domini Christophori Vrswyke illustrissimi regis Henrici vii quondam elemosynarii magni.

msItem.title: Preface to Gregory's Apology by its translator, Rufinus of Aquila
msItem.incipit: [rubr.] Ad Pronianum prologus Rufini de translatione libros Gregorii Nazanzeni episcopi. [text] Proficiscenti mihi ex urbe magnopere iniugebas, fili charissime, ut tibi absens quoque aliquid operis impenderem ...

msItem.title: Gregory's apology for his unworthiness for ordination to the priesthood
msItem.incipit: [rubr.] Gregorii Nanzanzeni Episcopi beatissimi viri quoque eruditiissimi qui theologus est appellatus et ex greco in latinum translatus. Appollogeticus Liber. [text] Victus sum et fateor me esse superatum. Subiectus sum domino et obsecravi eum ...
msItem.explicit: ... ut in templo eius omnes dicamus gloriam, grex simul et pastores, in Christo Jesu domino nostro, cui est gloria in secula seculorum, amen, in misericordiam. [f. 63r]

msItem.title: Ambrose's letter to Irenaeus
msItem.incipit: [rubr.] Sancti Ambrosii episcopi ad Ireneum: Pythagoricum mandatum commorantes, quo ille discipulos suos communem atque usitatam populo viam ingredi prohibuit, et ut idem a sacerdotibus conseruetur multiplici racione persuadentis epistola. [text] Ambrosius Ireneo: Pythagoricum mandatum in aliquorum scriptis predicari inuenimus ...
msItem.explicit: ... Vnde ei dictum legimus: Faciam te in Deum regi Pharaoni. Vale et nos, ut facis, quasi filius dilige! [closing rubr.] Omnipotenti Deo, Christi fere virgini Marie, toti celorum exerci tui, sit laus, honor, et gloria quorum adiutorio conscriptus est presens is libellus sumptibus et expensis reverendissimi domini Christophori Vrswyke decani, arte et industria Petri Meghen, monoculi theutonis Brabantini oppidi Buschiducensis. Anno serenissimi regis Henrici vii nonodecimo annoque Domini 1504. [f. 66v]

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 20 long lines (dimensions of written space: 150 x 83 mm); below line; frame ruled in lead; marginalia with manicules throughout.`

decoDesc.decoNote: Gold and red illuminated initials on leaves [3r], 1r and 63v; coat of arms on leaf [3r].

binding.p: Bound in 18th-century brown calf with gold tooling, rebacked in 20th century. Earlier English red morocco covers with narrow dentelle used as pastedowns; former marble endpapers bound as endleaves.

origin.p: Written in London, 1504, by Peter Meghen of Bois-le-Duc, Brabant, for Christopher Urswick, dean of Windsor and King Henry the VII's almoner; 1504

history.provenance: Formerly owned by Urswick (coat of arms, motto); given by John Mellerius to Thomas Makernes, 1674; [Ralph] Palmer library, 1747; Verney (bookplate); W.T. Smedley (bookplate); Purchased as part of the Smedley Collection in 1924 by Henry Clay Folger.

keywords.term: Maximus, of Turin, Saint, active 4th-5th century
Irenaeus, Saint, Bishop of Lyon, recipient
Ambrose, Saint, Bishop of Milan, -397, correspondent
